articles.title: If Microbes Entered the Olympics, These One-Celled Superstars Would Win Gold
articles.author: Reda√ß√£o
articles.excerpt:
If Microbes Entered the Olympics, These One-Celled Superstars Would Win Gold
They race, they spin, they shoot. Meet the organisms for which physical prowess is more than sport‚Äîit‚Äôs a matter of life...
articles.content:
If Microbes Entered the Olympics, These One-Celled Superstars Would Win Gold
They race, they spin, they shoot. Meet the organisms for which physical prowess is more than sport‚Äîit‚Äôs a matter of life and death
In winter sports, lugers slide at more than 90 miles per hour, hockey players send the puck zipping across the ice at 100 mph and figure skaters spin up to 342 rotations per minute. That‚Äôs fast.
But these human feats might not seem so impressive when compared with the speed demons of the microbial world. These minuscule predators and their prey hit high velocities during the chase. Hungry microbes make amazing leaps for food. Others hurl bits of their bodies or expand and contract with more force than astronauts experience at takeoff. Skier Lindsey Vonn has nothing on these speedsters.
Microbes accomplish these athletic feats even though they‚Äôre so small that their surroundings push back on them: A microbe paddling through water is like a skier trying to cut through a course neck-deep in honey. And they face life-or-death competitions in an unending evolutionary race. ‚ÄúThe small world is not a very kind world,‚Äù says Manu Prakash, a bioengineer and oceanographer at Stanford University and co-author of an article on ultrafast microbes in the 2025 Annual Review of Microbiology. ‚ÄúEither you are running away from something, or you are chasing something.‚Äù
Based on Prakash‚Äôs work, these speedy and powerful microbes deserve their own medals.
Fastest bacteria
For pure speed, the reigning champ is an egg-shaped bacterium called Candidatus Ovobacter propellens (its name remains unofficial because scientists haven‚Äôt yet fully described it or grown it alone in a test tube). Discovered half a meter deep in the sands off Denmark‚Äôs coast, it uses its 400 tail-like flagella to swim at up to one millimeter per second.
But that number is hard to put into perspective. Plus, pitting all microbes against each other in a single race would be unfair‚Äîsome are big and some are small, which means they face different resistance from their surroundings. So in their review, the authors calculated speed in terms of body lengths per second.
For O. propellens, a large-ish bacterium at four to five micrometers across, its top speed translates to about 200 body lengths per second. Using this metric, it is knocked off the winner‚Äôs podium by Magnetococcus marinus, a ball-shaped microbe just a micrometer or two across that swims at up to 500 body lengths per second. Compare that to luge, deemed the fastest winter Olympic sport, where athletes zoom at about 25 body lengths per second.
The M. marinus specimen that scientists clocked for speed was collected from estuary waters in Rhode Island. When researchers first set up a new 3D microscope to observe this speedster, it tumbled so rapidly that they had trouble assessing its path, recalls Damien Faivre, an interdisciplinary scientist at the University of Latvia.
After switching to a different microscope, Faivre and his colleagues saw that M. marinus swam in a helical trajectory like a figure skater performing a multirotation axel. It moves using two rotating bundles of seven flagella each, one in front and one in back. Tracing that corkscrew motion was key to awarding M. marinus its record, says Faivre. When the scientists calculated the microbe‚Äôs speed based on that total distance, ‚Äúit was actually traveling way more than expected.‚Äù
The bacterium is called Magnetococcus because it possesses a string of magnetite crystals that acts like a little compass, helping it navigate to the low-oxygen places it prefers. Someday, it might deliver medicines to the low-oxygen interiors of tumors: In a 2016 study, scientists stuck dozens of membranous satchels full of medicine all over the bacteria, injected them into mice and used magnets to guide them close to tumors. From there, the microbes‚Äô preferences for low oxygen drew more than half of them to penetrate the tumors.
Fastest archaea
Archaea belong to their own domain of microbes on the tree of life, as distinct from bacteria as humans are, and they were once thought to be slower swimmers.
Quick fact: What are archaea?
Archaea are single-celled organisms that thrive in extreme environments. Like bacteria, they do not have nuclei‚Äîbut archaea actually belong to an entirely different domain on the tree of life, separate from both bacteria and organisms with nucleus-containing cells, such as humans.
Scientists disproved that notion in a 2012 analysis. Their top speedster, by body length, was Methanocaldococcus villosus, and it could give M. marinus a run for its money. A roundish microbe one to two micrometers across that loves hot places and spews methane, it clocked in at up to 468 body lengths per second.
M. villosus was discovered in a hydrothermal vent north of Iceland. It uses its more than 50 flagella not just to swim, but also to attach to surfaces like the walls of ‚Äúblack smoker‚Äù chimneys around hydrothermal vents. Sometimes it uses those flagella to link with other M. villosus microbes.
This kind of speed generates heat. Take speed skater Erin Jackson, who won gold in Beijing in 2022 with a time of 37.04 seconds in the 500-meters. Propelling her 5-foot-5-inch body some 500 body lengths per second would have gotten her to the finish line in about 0.6 seconds. But a human athlete, if they could accomplish that, would explode, says Prakash. Microorganisms can be fast because they are small. They have more surface area for their volume than larger critters do, so they can release enough heat through exterior membranes.
Speedy squeezers
Figure skaters like Ilia Malinin tuck in their arms to spin faster, but the protozoan Spirostomum ambiguum performs a more extreme tuck. It can squish down to less than half the length of its wormlike one- to four-millimeter body in just five milliseconds.
But S. ambiguum isn‚Äôt leaping or spinning through the brackish waters it calls home. When it contracts, it squeezes out toxins to defend itself from predators. Prakash‚Äôs group reported that this superfast scrunch also generates a liquid vortex that tells neighboring cells something‚Äôs up. The wave, amplified as each microorganism squeezes in response, travels hundreds of times faster than the microbes can swim. Like ice hockey players working together, the microbial team synchronizes toxin-spewing.
As S. ambiguum scrunches, it feels acceleration of up to 15 G-forces, on the low end of what a jet fighter pilot would experience upon ejecting from an aircraft. This force should destroy the cell‚Äôs innards; if Malinin shrank to half his size, it‚Äôs safe to say he would never perform another axel. Prakash‚Äôs team found that S. ambiguum is protected by a meshwork of its own interior membranes that serves as a shock absorber.
Extreme expanders
If S. ambiguum does a big crunch, Pyrocystis noctiluca does the opposite: This glow-in-the-dark ocean plankton balloons to six times its starting size in under ten minutes.
P. noctiluca lives an up-and-down life, with each plankton transiting a vertical range of over 50 meters in the water column on a weekly round trip. Prakash, who described the rapid inflation in microbes collected off Hawaii, calls it the ‚Äúworld‚Äôs best marathon runner.‚Äù
At the top of the species‚Äô range, some 60 meters from the surface, P. noctiluca is 200 to 700 micrometers across. There, it uses photosynthesis to collect energy from sunlight. But it also needs nutrients more easily found deeper down. So it sinks, thanks to gravity, to as low as about 150 meters, where it completes its cell cycle, dividing in two.
But if those newborn cells drop too deep, they can‚Äôt overcome gravity and water pressure to rise. So they make what Prakash and colleagues describe as a ‚Äúslingshot‚Äù maneuver. The microbes suck in water and expand, diminishing their density so that they rise like buoys.
Super shooters
Our final speedster is a parasite that impales host cells with a harpoon that it can shoot at upwards of 300 micrometers per second. Anncaliia algerae is a type of microsporidium, a group containing more than 1,700 species that collectively infect most kinds of animals and contaminate waterways and foodstuffs. More than a dozen of these species, including A. algerae, can infect humans, though it‚Äôs unclear how often this happens. The infection can be asymptomatic or mild, causing a variety of symptoms, such as diarrhea. It can be fatal in people with weakened immune systems.
A. algerae floats along as a dormant, egg-shaped spore about four micrometers long, with its 100-micrometer-long harpoon, called the ‚Äúpolar tube,‚Äù coiled snugly within. Should that spore land in a suitable environment, such as someone‚Äôs small intestine, it shoots its shot. The harpoon‚Äôs speed might help it penetrate mucus coating the intestinal cells, speculates Gira Bhabha, a structural cell biologist at Johns Hopkins University.
Before the polar tube has even fully extended, the infectious material‚Äîat least two sets of fungal DNA, and perhaps the whole cell, Bhabha says‚Äîbegins a journey through it. Though the tube is just 100 nanometers wide, and the nuclei containing the DNA are seven times that size, somehow they squeeze through, moving almost as fast as the tube unfurls itself.
Microsporidia were discovered more than 150 years ago, but scientists are still trying to work out how they manage these physical feats. Bhabha and Prakash suspect that the harpoon may evert as it emerges, like a sock being flipped inside-out.
Studying microbial Olympians is about more than breaking records‚Äîit‚Äôs about defining the extremes that living things are capable of, says Prakash. These organisms exist in a completely different world from us, experiencing physical constraints and opportunities we don‚Äôt intuitively understand.
Plus, Prakash adds, figuring out that world could inspire novel inventions if the microbes‚Äô remarkable abilities could be adapted at human scales.
‚ÄúIn the extreme,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúalways lies a gem.‚Äù

articles.content:
These 15 Inspiring Images of Winter Sports Will Help You Rediscover Your Olympic Spirit
You don‚Äôt have to be an Olympian to enjoy these snowy activities
A skier takes advantage of several inches of snow covering blanketing the landscape, including trees that resemble piles of cotton balls, on Revelstoke Mountain in British Columbia.
James Woodin, Canada, 2020
These 15 Inspiring Images of Winter Sports Will Help You Rediscover Your Olympic Spirit
You don‚Äôt have to be an Olympian to enjoy these snowy activities
For some, freezing temperatures are a reason to stay indoors, huddled under blankets with a warm beverage and a roaring fire. For others, the perfect time to get out and enjoy the outdoors is when ice and snow are covering the landscape. Whether they‚Äôre enjoying relishing skating on ice, trekking through the snow or skiing down steep slopes, these adventurers consider a snowy scene an invitation‚Äîone they‚Äôre all too happy to accept.
The 2026 Olympic Winter Games will showcase the best of the world‚Äôs hockey players, skiers, ice skaters, speed skaters, bobsledders and other athletes, but you don‚Äôt have to be an Olympian to enjoy these sports. Wrap up in some warm outerwear and head to your nearest ice rink or powdery peak, but first, check out these 15 images from the Smithsonian Magazine Photo Contest.

articles.title: What‚Äôs Buried Beneath Antarctica's Ice? A New Map Unveils the Continent's Hidden Landscape Like Never Before Seen
articles.author: Reda√ß√£o
articles.excerpt:
What‚Äôs Buried Beneath Antarctica‚Äôs Ice? A New Map Unveils the Continent‚Äôs Hidden Landscape Like Never Before Seen
A better understanding of the bedrock can help researchers calculate how quickly the...
articles.content:
What‚Äôs Buried Beneath Antarctica‚Äôs Ice? A New Map Unveils the Continent‚Äôs Hidden Landscape Like Never Before Seen
A better understanding of the bedrock can help researchers calculate how quickly the continent‚Äôs melting glaciers might affect sea-level rise
Scientists have long known more about the surfaces of some other worlds than what lies beneath Antarctica‚Äôs ice sheet, which is up to three miles thick. A new approach to mapping could help change that.
A study published last month in the journal Science reveals an unprecedented map of Antarctica‚Äôs entire subglacial terrain, the landscape hiding below its hefty ice. The chart, created with satellite imagery and physics-based computer simulations, reveals thousands of previously unknown landforms and provides new details about mountains, canyons, valleys and other features.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like before, you had a grainy pixel film camera, and now, you‚Äôve got a properly zoomed-in digital image of what‚Äôs really going on,‚Äù says study co-author Helen Ockenden, a geoscientist at the University of Grenoble Alpes in France, to BBC News‚Äô Mark Poynting and Erwan Rivault.
Previous attempts to map Antarctica‚Äôs hidden terrain have used radar instruments dragged behind snowmobiles or suspended by planes. The tools emit radio waves that penetrate the ice sheet, get reflected off the bottom directly below and travel back to the surface. But the method typically follows specific tracks, leaving uncharted gaps up to dozens of miles wide.
‚ÄúIf you imagined the Scottish Highlands or the European Alps were covered by ice and the only way to understand their shape was the occasional flight several kilometers apart, there‚Äôs no way that you would see all these sharp mountains and valleys that we know to be there,‚Äù says study co-author Robert Bingham, a glaciologist at the University of Edinburgh in Scotland, to BBC.
To create the new map, the researchers combined satellite images of Antarctica‚Äôs surface with the physics of ice movement to estimate the subglacial topography. Just as water in a river flows differently if large rocks sit below it, the way that ice flows changes depending on the terrestrial features beneath it. The researchers ran computer simulations to calculate Antarctica‚Äôs entire hidden landscape and verified the output by comparing it to existing radar maps.
The work unveiled several previously unknown features, including more than 30,000 hills, defined as bumps at least about 160 feet tall. The team also found a steep-sided channel that‚Äôs about 160 feet deep, 3.7 miles wide and 250 miles long‚Äîroughly the distance between Washington, D.C., and New York City.
Need to know: Antarctica‚Äôs ice sheet
The continent is home to the world‚Äôs largest ice sheet, which covers roughly 5.4 million square miles. For comparison, the United States‚Äô entire land area encompasses about 3.5 million square miles.
‚ÄúThis is the start of a new approach to looking at what‚Äôs under the ice,‚Äù Stewart Jamieson, a glaciologist at Durham University in England, who was not involved in the work, tells Science‚Äôs Perri Thaler. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve known that this sort of thing ought to be possible, but it‚Äôs really about making that jump between possibility and producing this first product.‚Äù
But the technique has some limitations. Duncan Young, a glaciologist at the University of Texas at Austin who was not involved with the study, compares the researchers‚Äô method to predicting texture below a thick blanket. ‚ÄúYou can get a sense of what‚Äôs underneath the duvet, but it is not the complete story,‚Äù he tells Science. Radar, on the other hand, can capture those fine details. The researchers note in the study that their technique cannot distinguish landforms narrower than the ice is thick.
Still, having a continuous, accurate map of the terrain beneath Antarctica‚Äôs ice is ‚Äúcrucial,‚Äù Bingham tells Reuters‚Äô Will Dunham.
